and <u>Catoblepas Gnu<\u> the two sides of the bone converge and give 
it a truncated triangular form, which reaches a 
maximum in <u>Bubalus Caffir<\u> Fig 3. In <u>Bos Taurus<\u> also the anterior 
muscular impressions are supported by long tuberosities 
The basisphenoid is shorter thicker and stouter than in Bos, 
Bison <s>and<\s> or Bubalus and is untraversed by a median <s>line<\s> 
ridge* which is strongly marked in all these three animals. 
This ridge is inconstant in Capra and Ovis. The postero-
-inferior, or free edge of the pterygoid is inclined at a much 
more <s>acute<\s> ?obtuse angle to the presphenoid than in Bos or Bison 
while in <u>Bubalus Caffir<\u> it is nearly at a right angle. This 
Ovine <s>and Caprine<\s> character is shared also by the Gnu. 
The palatal surface of the Palatines and Maxillaries is more 
concave transversely than in the Ox, Buffalo and Bison, and 
much longer in proportion to its width. The Palate tapers 
gradually to the anterior edge of the Premaxillaries making 
but a slight detour round the anterior palatal foramen, 
instead of presenting the broad spatulate termination <s>of<\s> seen in all 
those three subgenera. All these are decidedly <s>Caprine and<\s> 
Ovine characteristics. In the Gnu the concavity and length 
of palate is united with the spatulate termination of the 
premaxillaries. The large space that the palatines of Ovibos 
take in the palate <s>is<\s> points to a bovine affinity. The Paramastoid process 
(paroccipital) tapers gradually to its apex in the Ovibos and the sheep 
<s>and the goat<\s>, <sand<\s> in Bubulus Caffir <s>it bears a tubercle for<\s> 
<s>the attachment of the stylolyal<\s> the latter is enlarged. 
The Occiput See Plate II is remarkable for its heighth, flatness and the strong 
development of the occipital or nuchal spine. the supra occipital 
encroaches on the coronal aspect of the skull where it articulates 
with the Parietal the suture between them remaining [text?] unobliterated (1)
